div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura [Eugenia Hook Carter], July 26, 1912
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT.
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
July 26 12
Rear Admiral JOHN G. WALKER,
United States Navy, CHAIRMAN.
Major General GEORGE W. DAVIS,
United States Army.
WILLIAM BARCLAY PARSONS, C. E.
WILLIAM H. BURR. C. E.
BENJAMIN M. HARROD, C. E.
C. EWALD GRUNSKY, C. E.
MR. FRANK J. HECKER.
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
Today I should hear from you again- The
boat is due Tuesday & we, except once, get the mail
Tuesday night or late afternoon. The next boat the “Ad-
vance” is a slow boat & is usually 12 hours late.

Tell Laura that the man Miss Lemman spoke of is
Dr. Nolan of Fauquier a very decent fellow & who may
make something of himself- He gets $1500, per annum
& “finds himself” so he is not over paid;

Someone wrote that Gorgas needed 300 physicians & I think he
has had 3000 applications- In point of fact except, the
service Men - (A. N. & M. H. S). There are 7 physicians on
the Isthmus one of whom was heired from the
French Canal Company, There will probably as many
more be needed by Xmas maybe 10 more, or even
15; many men would be in one another's way.
There are or will be shortly 3 from the army & 1 coming: 2
from Navy. 3 from M. H. S. & 2 coming. So we will hold
up our end of the work.

I have been engaged on a long report to the Commission
C1
B23
which I will finish tomorrow next day at any
rate before they get here Aug 2 or 3 - setting forth
what I need & why I need it.

It is after coffee & I am at the office now 7.15 A. M.
I enclose you a little piece of the sensitive plant-
Mimosa- I waded through a mass of it Sunday
about 4 1/2 feet high- it is almost a vine - & it
was astonishing to see the way it got out of
ones way- not only the leaves collapsed but the
vines twisted away from the touch. It left
a plain path almost as if cut

I enclose a letter to the Medical News, which
I want sent if the reprints have not appeared.
Tell Laura I rec'd, from Ned doubtless, Rizal's
Noli-Me-Tangere, but that I have not looked
in it, nor written to Ned, nor indeed which is
worse to Mother. I have had no time which
I felt, that I had a right to use. I am trying
to do my work & to share myself. & the two
things can both be done only by avoiding
everything I can avoid. I will, I think, have
time after the 3d of August, I have been
working too closely, but only once at night.
The view of the green wall of Ancon is still a perpetual delight to me

Rear Admiral JOHN G. WALKER,
United States Navy, CHAIRMAN.
Major General GEORGE W. DAVIS,
United States Army.
WILLIAM BARCLAY PARSONS, C. E.
WILLIAM H. BURR, C. E.
BENJAMIN M. HARROD, C. E.
C. EWALD GRUNSKY, C. E.
MR. FRANK J. HECKER.

It is possible, but a possibility which I
am loath to contemplate, that my last
letter to your mother. Laura & Ned, did not
reach them, because I put Canal Zone stamps
on them & mailed them on the steamer at Colon.
Now C. Z. stamps are no good except as letters mail-
ed in the zone; but the P. O. people tell me that it will
pretty certainly be delivered but& that extra postage
will be charged- Will I judge you will not grudge
2 cents for the letter. By the way the Panaman
stamps “surcharged Canal Zone” & Cancelled, may
he worth something- Perry has invested about
$60 00/100 in them, keep them. If worth 25 cents apiece
as he thinks, they are worth perserving

Gorgas & I. (after a coffee)- started out to climb-
Ancon - this morning - just at sunrize - we
tried 3 blind trails - evidently made by an-
imals which led no where in particular & it is
considered impossible (& is difficult) to go up
through the bush without a Machete. The best
trail, which we followed same ways, was an
ant trail! We finally walked around the
C1
B23
3
hill - about 3 miles & struck a trail by which
we reached the top. It was not so high by a
good deal as some of the Fanquier hills we
climbed together & not a rough as the first
one we went up through the woods, but it was
steep. There were places where standing straight
I could hold out my hand out horizontally & touch
the ground, the slope being about 60°. I can climb
many times better than Gorgas & reached
home perfectly fresh but decidedly wet
about 8.10 A M 8.10 °, we had on only pajamas, trousers
leggins shoes stockings & hats. We climbed, 620'
or rather that high above sea level - about 600'
think. Last evening a deer was found dead
near one of the wards - he had been shot & lost &
was carried out in the bushes. & certainly two
“tigres” - Jaguars - came for it last night.
It is certainly stones strange to think of such “var-
ment” close to civilization. No one saw the
things but their cry was mistaken for the
scream of a patient & we all ran out to
see what was the matter. There were certain-
ly two. How big they we there were, of course
The nights are still cool & it is fairly dry & dusty -
Running about 90° during the day. & cover comfort
able at night-
sun is unbearable
& I avoid it, exertion except a mile walk
twice a day - early & late I do not take.
